entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support non-special scheme URLs
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support non-special scheme URLs
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Support+non%5C-special+scheme+URLs%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support non-special scheme URLs</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Hayato+Ito%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Hayato Ito</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240808" rel="nofollow">Thu, 08 Aug 2024 01:09:47 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
hay...@chromium.org</pre><pre>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="http://bit.ly/url-non-special">http://bit.ly/url-non-special</a>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://url.spec.whatwg.org/">https://url.spec.whatwg.org/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#url-parsing">https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#url-parsing</a>>
Summary
Support non-special scheme URLs.
Previously, Chromium's URL parser didn't handle non-special scheme URLs properly. It treated these URLs as “opaque paths”, which didn’t align with the URL Standard.
Now, Chromium’s URL parser correctly processes non-special URLs.
Examples:
Before:
> const url = new URL("git://host/path");
> url.host
""
> url.pathname
"//host/path"
> url.host = "newhost";
> url.host
""
> const url = new URL("git://a b/path");
> url.pathname
"//a b/path"
After:
> const url = new URL("git://host/path");
> url.host
"host"
> url.pathname
"/path"
> url.host = "newhost";
> url.host
"newhost"
> url.href
"git://newhost/path"
> const url = new URL("git://a b/path");
=> throws Exception. // A space character is not allowed as a hostname.
See <a rel="nofollow" href="http://bit.ly/url-non-special">http://bit.ly/url-non-special</a> for more details.
As part of our Interop 2024 efforts, this change delivers the following improvements:
-
Boosts WPT URL Score: 936 previously failing subtests in the WPT URL tests (link
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LjxHl32fE4tCKugrK_PIso7mfXQVEeoD1wSnX2y0ZU8/edit?resourcekey=0-d1gP4X2sG7GPl9mlTeptIA&tab=t.0#heading=h.ji1rj1k19sgh">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LjxHl32fE4tCKugrK_PIso7mfXQVEeoD1wSnX2y0ZU8/edit?resourcekey=0-d1gP4X2sG7GPl9mlTeptIA&tab=t.0#heading=h.ji1rj1k19sgh</a>>) now pass, raising the score from 87.0% to 94.7%. -
Fixes code relying on incorrect URL behavior: 527 tests (link
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Pqw1iKXK_lxHj-kLIAeRFs-khFz-BPZDio1W7SgEVE4/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Pqw1iKXK_lxHj-kLIAeRFs-khFz-BPZDio1W7SgEVE4/edit?usp=sharing</a>>) and related code in Chromium that depended on the previous behavior are now fixed or mitigated, including: -
Web tests that relied on non-compliant non-special URL behavior (e.g. “javascript://a b” URL) -
Non-special schemes used internally by Chromium code base, including ChromeOS (e.g. “steam:”, “materialized-view://”, “cros-apps://”)
Blink component
Internals>Network <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Internals%3ENetwork">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Internals%3ENetwork</a>>
TAG review
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Since Safari and Firefox already support non-special scheme URLs, the likelihood of public websites breaking due to this change is likely low. See here <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LjxHl32fE4tCKugrK_PIso7mfXQVEeoD1wSnX2y0ZU8/edit?resourcekey=0-d1gP4X2sG7GPl9mlTeptIA&tab=t.0">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LjxHl32fE4tCKugrK_PIso7mfXQVEeoD1wSnX2y0ZU8/edit?resourcekey=0-d1gP4X2sG7GPl9mlTeptIA&tab=t.0</a>> for a rough estimation of the non-special scheme URL usages.
Gecko: Shipped
WebKit: Shipped
Web developers: Generally seems positive.
Some signals (from interop 2024 discussions <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/424">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/424</a>>) are:
-
> Confusion because URL parsers across Blink, Gecko, WebKit, Node, and Deno do not interop well. The root cause is nearly always parser bugs in Blink or Gecko: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://twitter.com/oleg008/status/1699087223751073883">https://twitter.com/oleg008/status/1699087223751073883</a>
-
> URL is very widely used - custom schemes are commonly used for links to native apps, or when dealing with developer tooling like databases. They may also become exceedingly more common with import maps.
Other potential risks and assessments:
-
Enterprise usage: It's difficult to predict how non-special URLs are used in the wild, especially by enterprise customers with in-house apps. While adding an Enterprise Policy was considered to mitigate risks, technical limitations make it difficult to support URLs. See <a rel="nofollow" href="http://bit.ly/url-non-special">http://bit.ly/url-non-special</a> for more info. We'll disable the feature with Finch (StandardCompliantNonSpecialSchemeURLParsing flag) in case this causes serious issues. -
Impacts on well-known non-special schemes: See here
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LjxHl32fE4tCKugrK_PIso7mfXQVEeoD1wSnX2y0ZU8/edit?resourcekey=0-d1gP4X2sG7GPl9mlTeptIA&tab=t.0#heading=h.k3rirdjyomw6">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LjxHl32fE4tCKugrK_PIso7mfXQVEeoD1wSnX2y0ZU8/edit?resourcekey=0-d1gP4X2sG7GPl9mlTeptIA&tab=t.0#heading=h.k3rirdjyomw6</a>> for the impacts on “javascript://”, “data:”, and so on. -
Impacts on dependent components: This change affects components relying on URL behavior, like Origin <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#origin">https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#origin</a>>. See the Security section below.
Security
In Chromium, GURL, KURL, and web-facing URL APIs share the common URL parser backends, which reside in //url. As a result, this web-facing change will also affect core components like url::Origin, kurl::SecurityOrigin.
For detailed information on how url::Origin, kurl::SecurityOrigin, and web-facing url.origin are impacted, please refer to this CL’s description <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5309015">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5309015</a>>.
TL;DR. This is a complex issue due to historical reasons. While most components remain unaffected, there are some nuances, particularly regarding the “Android WebView Hack”. We’ve preserved the current Origin behavior for Android WebView.
WebView application risks
Beyond the aforementioned "Android WebView Hack", there are no other changes specific to WebView.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, Chrome OS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
Yes (dashboard <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/url?label=master&label=experimental&product=chrome&product=firefox&product=safari&aligned&view=interop&q=label%3Ainterop-2023-url">https://wpt.fyi/results/url?label=master&label=experimental&product=chrome&product=firefox&product=safari&aligned&view=interop&q=label%3Ainterop-2023-url</a>> )
Flag name
StandardCompliantNonSpecialSchemeURLParsing
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/1416006">https://crbug.com/1416006</a>
Estimated milestones
M130
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5201116810182656">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5201116810182656</a>
Links to previous Intent discussions
Previous I2S <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/wYuPrIQzDTA/m/uoL4bXR2BgAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/wYuPrIQzDTA/m/uoL4bXR2BgAJ</a>>. The previous I2S mail was sent last year but please consider this intent to ship as a new one.
-- Hayato

To view this discussion on the web visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAFpjS_1_R%3D%2BHXYgTCuLD_WGR0foLKVnxAU9am1QbHyAZ%3D%2B3Ohw%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAFpjS_1_R%3D%2BHXYgTCuLD_WGR0foLKVnxAU9am1QbHyAZ%3D%2B3Ohw%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Deprecate+and+Remove%5C%3A+Remove+CanvasRenderingContext2D+method+scrollPathIntoView%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Remove CanvasRenderingContext2D method scrollPathIntoView</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240808" rel="nofollow">Thu, 08 Aug 2024 06:30:41 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails schen...@chromium.org </pre><pre>
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/8216">https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/8216</a>
Summary
The scrollPathIntoView method on CanvasRenderingContext2D was implemented in Chrome behind a flag, but never shipped and never implemented by any other browsers in the nearly 10 years of its existence. The WHATWG has agreed to remove the method due to lack of interest. It has zero usage according to the stats, and MDN says it is not implemented anywhere. We are removing the method and associated flag and tests.
Blink component Blink>Canvas
Motivation
The scrollPathIntoView method has been in the spec since 2011 and no browsers have shipped it yet, though there is an experimental implementation hidden behind a runtime flag in Chromium. There seems to be no implementer or web developer interest for this feature: No usage reported in chromestatus No related outstanding issues in the chromium issue tracker. No activity on the WebKit issue until it was just closed: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=149987">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=149987</a> Firefox bug has been open for 10 years with no activity: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1120401">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1120401</a> It was agreed by WHATWG to remove the method after a suggestion from Justin Novosad, and there is even a WPT test ensuring it is removed (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/html/canvas/historical.window.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/html/canvas/historical.window.html</a>, "CanvasRenderingContext2D.scrollPathIntoView method is removed"). It has now been removed from the spec and from MDN.

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Extend+Experiment%5C%3A+Captured+Surface+Control%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Extend Experiment: Captured Surface Control</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240812" rel="nofollow">Mon, 12 Aug 2024 06:22:09 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails elada...@chromium.org, gui...@chromium.org </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/screen-share/captured-surface-control/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/screen-share/captured-surface-control/blob/main/README.md</a>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://screen-share.github.io/captured-surface-control">https://screen-share.github.io/captured-surface-control</a>
Design docs
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/10UojDvTJ6ojBEOP7cgBIIaE7WZEfes_Qv1eN3A2A0nM/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/10UojDvTJ6ojBEOP7cgBIIaE7WZEfes_Qv1eN3A2A0nM/edit?usp=sharing</a>
Summary
Web API that allows Web applications to: 1. Produce wheel events in a captured tab or window. 2. Read/write the zoom level of a captured tab.
Blink component Blink>GetDisplayMedia
TAG review <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/962">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/962</a>

Origin Trial documentation link <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/screen-share/captured-surface-control/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/screen-share/captured-surface-control/blob/main/README.md</a>
WebFeature UseCounter name kCapturedSurfaceControl

Interoperability and Compatibility

Security
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/screen-share/captured-surface-control?tab=readme-ov-file#security-and-privacy-concerns">https://github.com/screen-share/captured-surface-control?tab=readme-ov-file#security-and-privacy-concerns</a>
WebView application risks

Goals for experimentation
Reason this experiment is being extended
The status in the W3C WebRTC WG is that we have consensus on supporting the use case of forwarding zoom and wheel events from the local user to the captured tab. The API currently under trial supports this use case, but the WG does not want support use cases with non-local control (eg, co-presenting), which the current API does support. See <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/2024/05/21-webrtc-minutes.html#t01">https://www.w3.org/2024/05/21-webrtc-minutes.html#t01</a> We want to experiment with an alternative API shape to prevent non-local use cases, and with additional restrictions on the existing API shape. These changes will be discussed in upcoming WG meetings.
Reason this experiment is being extended
The experiment was shifted from the original m122-m127 to m124-m129. See <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/7MbIEBdHMck">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/7MbIEBdHMck</a> for details.
Ongoing technical constraints

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Direct+Sockets+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Direct Sockets API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240813" rel="nofollow">Tue, 13 Aug 2024 06:59:06 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails greengr...@google.com </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/direct-sockets/blob/main/docs/explainer.md">https://github.com/WICG/direct-sockets/blob/main/docs/explainer.md</a>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/direct-sockets">https://wicg.github.io/direct-sockets</a>
Summary
Allows Isolated Web Apps to establish direct transmission control protocol (TCP) and user datagram protocol (UDP) communications with network devices and systems as well as listen to and accept incoming connections.
Blink component Blink>Network>Direct Sockets
Search tags networking, TCP, UDP, sockets
TAG review <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/548">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/548</a>
TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Other browsers may choose to implement this API.
Gecko: Closed Without a Position (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/431">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/431</a>)
WebKit: No signal
Web developers: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://discourse.wicg.io/t/filling-the-remaining-gap-between-websocket-webrtc-and-webtranspor/4366">https://discourse.wicg.io/t/filling-the-remaining-gap-between-websocket-webrtc-and-webtranspor/4366</a>) Numerous potential use cases have been suggested.
Other signals:
Security
Various security risks and mitigations are noted in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/raw-sockets/blob/master/docs/explainer.md#security-considerations">https://github.com/WICG/raw-sockets/blob/master/docs/explainer.md#security-considerations</a> This is a powerful API. Users will have the opportunity to give Isolated Web Apps access to local hardware, and information systems behind organization firewalls. Mitigations are designed to ensure this cannot happen accidentally, and only through enterprise policies or the friction of installing a native app.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
N/A. Feature not compiled in Android.
Debuggability
The code using this API can be debugged using the standard tools. Integrating the API with the DevTools Networking tab to enable easier introspection of the state of these connections as well as the data transferred could be a beneficial future improvement.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? No This feature is implemented on desktop platforms, although it will only be available to the end users on platforms that support Isolated Web Apps, which is currently only ChromeOS. Android is excluded for historical reasons, although there are no apparent interoperability blockers here.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes These tests require a specific --isolated-context-origins flag to be tested in WPTs, so they're run as a part of a virtual suite and are not reflected on wpt.fyi.
Flag name on chrome://flags #enable-direct-sockets-web-api
Finch feature name DirectSockets
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=909927">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=909927</a>
Launch bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4339602">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4339602</a>
Measurement We have the following histograms for tracking network failures upon creating sockets (prefixed with DirectSockets.*): - TCPNetworkFailures - UDPNetworkFailures - TCPServerNetworkFailures Separate programmatic counters for the .idl methods and attributes (via MeasureAs) are also included to track the stats for API usage.
Availability expectation Feature is available only in Isolated Web Apps on desktop platforms. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5146307550248960">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5146307550248960</a>
Adoption expectation Expected to be used initially by a small number of developers inside Isolated Web Apps.
Adoption plan Working directly with developers that are planning to rely on the API.
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function? None
Sample links
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/telnet-client">https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/telnet-client</a>
Estimated milestones

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Element+Reflection%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Element Reflection</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240814" rel="nofollow">Wed, 14 Aug 2024 07:28:19 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">

Thanks
Alice
On 2024-08-08 02:04, Daniel Bratell wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Hi from the future!
About Element Reflection, I'm curious if anyone is still working on this or if we should let go of this intent until some future time?
/Daniel On 2024-02-01 01:16, 'Vladimir Levin' via blink-dev wrote:
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> On Wed, Jan 31, 2024 at 6:14 PM Alice Boxhall <al...@igalia.com> wrote:
On Thursday, February 1, 2024 at 6:52:13 AM UTC+11 vmp...@google.com wrote:
On Wed, Jan 31, 2024 at 10:10 AM alice <al...@igalia.com> wrote: Contact emails al...@igalia.com, mere...@chromium.org
Explainer
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/aom/blob/gh-pages/aria-reflection-explainer.md#reflecting-element-references">https://github.com/WICG/aom/blob/gh-pages/aria-reflection-explainer.md#reflecting-element-references</a> </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Specification
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-dom-interfaces.html#reflecting-content-attributes-in-idl-attributes:element">https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-dom-interfaces.html#reflecting-content-attributes-in-idl-attributes:element</a> </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/aria/#ARIAMixin">https://w3c.github.io/aria/#ARIAMixin</a>
Summary This feature allows for ARIA relationship attributes to be reflected in IDL as element references rather than DOMStrings.
Note: This intent specifically concerns the ARIA attributes using Element Reflection, i.e. the attributes in the ARIAMixin interface with a type of Element or FrozenArray<Element>. popoverTargetElement, which also uses Element Reflection, is already shipping in Blink and WebKit.
Blink component Blink>DOM
TAG review <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/134">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/134</a>
TAG review status Issues addressed
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Gecko: Under consideration <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/200">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/200</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1769586">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1769586</a>
WebKit: Shipped/Shipping
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-technology-preview-release-notes/stp-release-151">https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-technology-preview-release-notes/stp-release-151</a>) </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Mentioned in STP release notes:
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-technology-preview-release-notes/stp-release-151">https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-technology-preview-release-notes/stp-release-151</a> </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Was shipped in Safari 16.4 but wasn't mentioned in release notes there.
Web developers: Requested by Web Component authors in particular as a means to implement ARIA relationships for elements inside of Shadow DOM.
I wonder if you had any feedback from framework authors that use VDOM. For context, we were considering using element references for a different feature, and couldn't overcome the fact that when frameworks change DOM, sometimes Nodes and Elements are removed or reused for a different purpose than when initially constructed (ie the element that used to represent the first item in the list is now used to represent the third item in the list).
I realize that this is asking a question very late in the design process, but I'm just curious if that's a case that you considered and if so how you reasoned about it. </pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> To be honest, no, we didn't take VDOM into account.
I'd be curious to hear what specific cases you were running into difficulty with, but it does seem like these paradigms are fundamentally at odds with one another - if elements are unpredictably destroyed and recreated, then it seems like using the string ID-based version is going to be a better fit. This API is, at least, designed to work with using the `setAttribute()` version, in that setting the content attribute will cause any value set via the IDL attribute to be discarded (and vice-versa).
The main use case for us was just matching elements automatically across DOM mutations with a caveat that we were using CSS, not attributes. We couldn't really get a sense of how stable our proposals were because of the VDOM type of reordering. It might be worthwhile for us to revisit that plan. I agree with you that I think your case is a lot better, since it affects attributes being set, instead of being some ephemeral state that the browser keeps track of.
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> (VDOM has always made me anxious for similar reasons - if elements are unpredictably moved or destroyed, what happens if an assistive technology was visiting those nodes in the accessibility tree when that happens? But I have essentially no experience actually using it, so presumably that can be managed in practice.) </pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> I also agree with this sentiment. <div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Implement+%5C%26+Ship%5C%3A+Transferable+RTCDataChannel+to+dedicated+workers%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Implement & Ship: Transferable RTCDataChannel to dedicated workers</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240814" rel="nofollow">Wed, 14 Aug 2024 08:47:38 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM1
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2024-08-09 01:21, Thomas Guilbert wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Contact emails
tguilb...@chromium.org
Explainer
None
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-extensions/#rtcdatachannel-transferable">https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-extensions/#rtcdatachannel-transferable</a>
Summary
</pre><tt>The RTCDataChannel interface is part of the WebRTC standard, and </tt><tt>represents a network channel which can be used for bidirectional </tt><tt>peer-to-peer transfers of arbitrary data. This feature tracks exposing </tt><tt>RTCDataChannel in dedicated workers, and allowing the transfer of </tt><tt>RTCDataChannels to them workers. This will help reduce main thread </tt><tt>contention and lead to smoother and more reliable WebRTC applications. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Blink component
</pre><tt>Blink>WebRTC>DataChannel </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EWebRTC%3EDataChannel">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EWebRTC%3EDataChannel</a>> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
</pre><tt>There is an interoperability risk when it comes to which types of </tt><tt>workers are supported by which browser. - Safari/WebKit supports </tt><tt>transfers to DedicatedWorkers and to ServiceWorkers. - Chromium is </tt><tt>only looking to add transfers to DedicatedWorkers; supporting </tt><tt>transfers to ServiceWorkers would require significant architectural </tt><tt>changes (across processes, rather than across threads) and might never </tt><tt>be supported. - Firefox/Gecko supports neither, but might support </tt><tt>transfers to both DedicatedWorkers and ServiceWorkers, if/when they </tt><tt>choose to support this feature. Regardless of whether or not Chromium </tt><tt>supports transfers to ServiceWorkers, enabling transfers to </tt><tt>DedicatedWorkers addresses current developer needs, and improves </tt><tt>interoperability. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>/Gecko/: No signal </tt><tt>(<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1209163">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1209163</a>) Mozilla is </tt><tt>aware of the issue, but has not allocated resources to it as of yet. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>/WebKit/: Shipped/Shipping </tt><tt>(<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=222965">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=222965</a>) </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>/Web developers/: Positive This has been a longstanding request from </tt><tt>developers. E.g: </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1209163#c4">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1209163#c4</a> </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40787712#comment21">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40787712#comment21</a> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Other signals/:
Ergonomics
</pre><tt>This feature improves the ergonomics of existing Worker exposed APIs. </tt><tt>For example, it allows developers to use WebCodecs and Offscreen </tt><tt>canvas from workers, without having to repeatedly transfer data from </tt><tt>the main thread. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Activation
N/A
Security
</pre><tt>This feature should not introduce any new security risks. Existing </tt><tt>risks can be found in the WebRTC API specification: </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-pc/#privacy-and-security-considerations">https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-pc/#privacy-and-security-considerations</a> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
WebView application risks
</pre><tt>Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such </tt><tt>that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
None
Debuggability
N/A
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
Yes
</pre><tt>DedicatedWorkers: </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-extensions/transfer-datachannel.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-extensions/transfer-datachannel.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a> </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-extensions/transfer-datachannel.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-extensions/transfer-datachannel.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>> </tt><tt>ServiceWorkers (out of scope for this feature): </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-extensions/transfer-datachannel-service-worker.https.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-extensions/transfer-datachannel-service-worker.https.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a> </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-extensions/transfer-datachannel-service-worker.https.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-extensions/transfer-datachannel-service-worker.https.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">

Summary
Modifies the Private Aggregation API to merge histogram contributions with the same bucket and filtering ID before embedding in the aggregatable report's encrypted payload. Private Aggregation imposes a limit on the number of contributions that can be embedded in a single aggregatable report, with any additional contributions being dropped. By merging together contributions where possible, we can get additional utility out of the limit. Note that, ignoring the dropping of excess contributions, merging these sorts of contributions should not have any impact on the final outputs (i.e. summary reports).

Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/future-browsing-context-group-dependency-hint">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/future-browsing-context-group-dependency-hint</a></pre><pre>
SpecificationNone Note: See here <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/future-browsing-context-group-dependency-hint?tab=readme-ov-file#specification-changes">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/future-browsing-context-group-dependency-hint?tab=readme-ov-file#specification-changes</a>> for intended changes to the html spec.
Summary
Extends the use of the "opener" rel type to same-window navigations to signal to the browser that the destination page will open a new window and the referring page expects to be able to access it. Some user agents perform browsing context group changes on navigation that aren't strictly necessary for security in order to improve performance. This results in named window reuse not being possible across a back navigation. Annotating an anchor element with "opener" will signal to the user agent that performing a browsing context group change would break a future opener relationship.
Blink componentBlink>Internals>Frames <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EInternals%3EFrames">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EInternals%3EFrames</a>>
TAG reviewNone
Note: See here <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/979">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/979</a>> for the early design review.
TAG review statusPending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
WebKit wouldn't have to make any changes. They already have the intended behaviour of reusing the existing window, without the use of the proposed annotation, and would be aligned with the spec changes. If Firefox wishes to adopt this behaviour, I wouldn't expect architectural difficulties in doing so. It's a matter of passing a bool through to their isolation logic. Alternatively, it would be fine from a spec perspective if they wish to keep the existing behaviour. The use of an opener rel on a link that targets the same window currently has no effect. There are a small number of pages that do this anyway (see use counter [1]). The only negative effect such pages would experience is a potential unintentional loss of bfcache eligibility. Compared to the lack of clarity from creating a new rel type, this seems worth it. For user agents that don't recognize an "opener" window feature, this could change the window selection to a popup instead of a tab. This wouldn't matter for _self navigations. But in any case, a page could explicitly use the feature "popup=0" to avoid this. [1] <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4742">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4742</a>
*Gecko*: No signal ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1059">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1059</a>)
*WebKit*: No signal ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/383">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/383</a>)
*Web developers*: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40281878">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40281878</a>) The reporter of the motivating bug has indicated that this proposal would enable their use case without bfcache-ineligibility hacks.
*Other signals*:
Security
No concerns expected. This is not introducing a new capability. It's a more targeted opt-out mechanism for behaviour that can already be achieved. Also note that the page can only use this to avoid optional BCG changes that aren't needed for security. Notably, it can't be used to avoid COOP enforcement.
WebView application risks

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Language+Detector+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Language Detector API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Domenic+Denicola%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Domenic Denicola</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240815" rel="nofollow">Thu, 15 Aug 2024 00:13:32 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emailsdome...@chromium.org, fer...@chromium.org, kenjibah...@chromium.org</pre><pre>
Explainer<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/translation-api/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/WICG/translation-api/blob/main/README.md</a>
(This explainer bundles together the translator API and the language detector API, since they are very related. This Intent is only for the language detector API.)
SpecificationNone yet, although we're excited to start writing one during the trial.
Summary
A JavaScript API for detecting the language of text, with confidence levels.
Blink componentBlink>AI>Language Detection <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EAI%3ELanguage%20Detection">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EAI%3ELanguage%20Detection</a>>
TAG review<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/948">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/948</a>
TAG review statusIssues open: "satisfied with concerns", mainly around naming.
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This feature, like all built-in AI features, has inherent interoperability risks due to the use of AI models whose behavior is not fully specified. See some general discussion in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/reports/ai-web-impact/#interop">https://www.w3.org/reports/ai-web-impact/#interop</a>. By providing a high-level API with clear output formats, as well as a capabilities API for detecting what a given browser supports, we believe we can guide web developers toward using the API in an interoperable way that does not depend on the specific models that a given browser or browser version uses.
*Gecko*: No signal ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1015">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1015</a>)
*WebKit*: No signal ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/339">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/339</a>)
*Web developers*: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/proposals/issues/147">https://github.com/WICG/proposals/issues/147</a>)
*Other signals*:
Ergonomics
This API will likely frequently be used in concert with the translator API ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5172811302961152">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5172811302961152</a>). Our current implementation is tied up with the browser's built-in language detection, which runs on the main thread. Alternative architectures are possible and we're exploring the implications of the current one through the origin trial process.
Activation
This feature would definitely benefit from having polyfills, backed by any of: cloud services, lazily-loaded on-device models using WebGPU, or the web developer's own server. We anticipate seeing an ecosystem of such polyfills grow as more developers experiment with this API.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Goals for experimentation
Our main goal for the origin trial is to get feedback on model quality and performance when faced with real-world use cases from developers. For example, we are interested in how often multilingual input is provided and what developers expect for such cases ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/translation-api/issues/13">https://github.com/WICG/translation-api/issues/13</a>).
We also expect to get some feedback on the API shape (which will likely evolve throughout the trial), and how limiting the current architecture's ability to only run after page load is.
Ongoing technical constraints
None.
Debuggability
Basic tooling suffices
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?No.
We hope to work on web platform tests for this feature, but how much we can guarantee as testable beyond the surface API is unclear. For example, since no specific languages are guaranteed to be supported, it's not clear we can actually test language detection. APIs to mock the results might help here.

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A+HTML+handwriting+attribute%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: HTML handwriting attribute</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Adam+Ettenberger%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Adam Ettenberger' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240812" rel="nofollow">Mon, 12 Aug 2024 16:03:51 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Some of the pros/cons of `touch-action: handwriting` keyword over the `handwriting` attribute:</pre><pre>
Pros:
- Matches existing expectations around the `touch-action` CSS property, developers can choose to enable handwriting or not. - Requires a relatively small code change, both for Chromium implementation and for web developers to control where handwriting should be allowed. - Allows developers to individually specify whether stylus handwriting or touch scrolling should be enabled. - This wouldn't be possible without using preventDefault to bypass handwriting and then manually handle stylus scrolling with something like scrollTo. - For example, developers could specify: - `touch-action: manipulation` to allow stylus handwriting, and both touch scrolling and touch zoom - `touch-action: pinch-zoom handwriting` to allow stylus handwriting and touch zoom, but disallow scrolling - `touch-action: pinch-zoom pan-x pan-y` to allow scrolling and touch zoom, but disallow handwriting
Cons:
- ~40% of sites specify `touch-action` and may need treatment to enable handwriting if used in the context of editable text. - Chrome Platform Status (chromestatus.com) <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/css/timeline/popularity/421">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/css/timeline/popularity/421</a>> - Property keywords are opt-in when any are specified (default is opt-out by including all keywords). So sites specifying any keywords other than `auto`, `inherit`, or `manipulation` on editable text or ancestors of them will need to be considered by site developers. - i.e., Sites that may want handwriting could unintentionally have it disabled once the experience becomes available, needing to update the site to allow the experience. - It's unclear from the chrome status page *which *keywords are being used or if they're being used in editable context, so not enough information to gauge the full impact.
---
The main issue with the existing non-standard behavior where handwriting is tied to having both `pan-x pan-y` specified is developers cannot choose whether a stylus stroke should be interpreted as handwriting or scrolling when applicable. By specifying any `touch-action` that doesn't include both, the developer loses both handwriting and scrolling (one or both directions). The existing implementation is more difficult for developers, for example full-screen and/or paginated text editors, to control whether stylus should handwrite or scroll, since it necessitates taking control of all relevant stylus inputs to manually handle scrolling instead of handwriting.
Including a keyword to allow developers to make this distinction will at least make it easier for developers to disable handwriting or scrolling independently for scenarios where the only viable alternative is to manually handle all stylus inputs.

entry.title: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Experiment: Reduce Accept-Language
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Experiment: Reduce Accept-Language
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Reduce+Accept%5C-Language%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Re: Intent to Experiment: Reduce Accept-Language</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Eli+Grey%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Eli Grey' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240810" rel="nofollow">Sat, 10 Aug 2024 16:14:58 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Restricting accept-language to 'common combinations' is fundamentally at odds with personal agency. This can break the web for people with uncommon combinations of accepted languages. This change would effectively discriminate against these people by denying them access to websites in their preferred languages that previously worked just fine.</pre><pre>
Language preferences should not be ignored just because they're unique, and therefore trackable.
On Wednesday, August 7, 2024 at 8:41:48 AM UTC-7 vict...@chromium.org wrote:
Email Body
Contact emails
vict...@chromium.org, mike...@chromium.org
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language</a>
TAG reviewTo be filed. Summary
In order to reduce the amount of passively available entropy in HTTP requests, we want to reduce the amount of information the Accept-Language header exposes in HTTP requests and JS interface navigator.languages. Instead of sending every user's language preferences via Accept-Language, we only send the user’s most preferred language after language negotiation in the Accept-Language header. For the HTTP Accept-Language header, we will potentially expand a base language based on the language-region pair (e.g., if the preferred language is “en-US” we will expand to “en-US, en;q=0.9”). The JS getter navigator.languages returns the same value as navigator.language.
We would like to run a Finch 1% experiment from M128 to M131 inclusive.
Blink component
Privacy>Fingerprinting <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Privacy%3EFingerprinting">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Privacy%3EFingerprinting</a>>
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
The compatibility risk is relatively low for most users since we're planning to reduce the amount of information in the Accept-Language header and navigator.languages, rather than remove the header or change value format in the header. Most existing Accept-Language detection code should continue to work. This experiment should help us validate this assumption and identify corner cases.
As for interoperability, for multilingual sites to rely on the Accept-Language, developers would need to depend on a user's full Accept-Language list for some browsers and a primary user's Accept-Language for others. Another signal is that the Chrome incognito model already reduced the Accept-Language header and JS interface navigator.languages to one language, and Safari ships this behavior for many users today.
Gecko: Pending (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1014">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1014</a>)
WebKit: Shipped (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/338">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/338</a>) Safari already reduced the Accept-Language to a single language in most cases.
Web developers: Some web developers are concerned about the client-side language negotiation implications ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Tanych/accept-language/issues/10">https://github.com/Tanych/accept-language/issues/10</a>).
Experiment Goals
The goal of this experiment is to ensure web compatibility with our proposed changes. Developers can also test how reducing the Accept-Language request header and the JS getter navigator.languages will affect their systems via the chrome://flags/#reduce-accept-language flag, especially to understand the impact on client side language negotiation via navigator.languages. We will be relying heavily on user and developer feedback to identify where breakage occurs, or where use cases are not accounted for, especially for multilingual sites depending on the Accept-Language header, and navigator.languages.
Experiment Risks
There are some risks, as many multilingual sites have come to rely on the value in Accept-Language header and JS interfaces navigator.languages to send the right representation pages to the user. Site breakage can take many forms, both obvious and non-obvious - which is the point of running this experiment. If we are confident the design is largely web-compatible, we will request a Deprecation Trial for sites to be able to have time to migrate or modify how their sites work.
Debuggability
Both of these settings and the resulting network requests are visible in DevTools.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, Chrome OS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No (All but WebView)
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
No (We fully test in browser_tests, WPT has limits to cover all the test cases in the Accept-Language header).

Specification

Summary
The scrollPathIntoView method on CanvasRenderingContext2D was implemented in Chrome behind a flag, but never shipped and never implemented by any other browsers in the nearly 10 years of its existence. The WHATWG has agreed to remove the method due to lack of interest. It has zero usage according to the stats, and MDN says it is not implemented anywhere. We are removing the method and associated flag and tests.
Blink component
Blink>Canvas
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3ECanvas">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3ECanvas</a>>
Motivation
The scrollPathIntoView method has been in the spec since 2011 and no browsers have shipped it yet, though there is an experimental implementation hidden behind a runtime flag in Chromium. There seems to be no implementer or web developer interest for this feature: No usage reported in chromestatus No related outstanding issues in the chromium issue tracker. No activity on the WebKit issue until it was just closed: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=149987">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=149987</a> Firefox bug has been open for 10 years with no activity: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1120401">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1120401</a> It was agreed by WHATWG to remove the method after a suggestion from Justin Novosad, and there is even a WPT test ensuring it is removed (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/html/canvas/historical.window.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/html/canvas/historical.window.html</a>, "CanvasRenderingContext2D.scrollPathIntoView method is removed"). <div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Reduce+Accept%5C-Language%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Reduce Accept-Language</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240808" rel="nofollow">Thu, 08 Aug 2024 11:47:12 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> Hey Philip,
</pre><tt>Yes - we have discussed this a little bit, and are open to finalizing on </tt><tt>that as a solution. But we'd like to gather some baseline metrics on the </tt><tt>most minimal version first (which is the point of this experiment), and </tt><tt>explore other solutions depending on compat impact (which we plan to </tt><tt>measure in a handful of ways, including number of times users are trying </tt><tt>to use the in-browser translation feature). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre>
later, Mike
On 8/7/24 11:59 AM, Philip Jägenstedt wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>Looking at the alternatives considered </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language?tab=readme-ov-file#considered-alternatives">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language?tab=readme-ov-file#considered-alternatives</a>>, </tt><tt>I wonder if you've also explored identifying common combinations of </tt><tt>languages, and limiting the header to the most common current values </tt><tt>of the header? The combination of a small language like Swedish and a </tt><tt>large language (English, Chinese, Spanish, etc) in some order is </tt><tt>probably very common. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>Heads up that I am going OOO, so I won't be able to follow up, so </tt><tt>don't block this intent on me. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On Wed, Aug 7, 2024 at 5:51 PM Alex Russell <slightly...@chromium.org> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Hey Victor,
As you know, removal of entropy is not in and of itself a useful goal. A large number of users on the web are bi-lingual. Is there any analysis that this will do more good than harm?
Thanks,
Alex
On Wed, Aug 7, 2024 at 8:41 AM Victor Tan <victor...@chromium.org> wrote:
Email Body
Contact emails
victor...@chromium.org <<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:victor...@chromium.org">mailto:victor...@chromium.org</a>>, miketa...@chromium.org <<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:miketa...@chromium.org">mailto:miketa...@chromium.org</a>>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language</a>>
TAG review
To be filed.
Summary
In order to reduce the amount of passively available entropy in HTTP requests, we want to reduce the amount of information the Accept-Language header exposes in HTTP requests and JS interface navigator.languages. Instead of sending every user's language preferences via Accept-Language, we only send the user’s most preferred language after language negotiation in the Accept-Language header. For the HTTP Accept-Language header, we will potentially expand a base language based on the language-region pair (e.g., if the preferred language is “en-US” we will expand to “en-US, en;q=0.9”). The JS getter navigator.languages returns the same value as navigator.language.
We would like to run a Finch 1% experiment from M128 to M131 inclusive.
Blink component
Privacy>Fingerprinting
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Privacy%3EFingerprinting">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Privacy%3EFingerprinting</a>>
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
The compatibility risk is relatively low for most users since we're planning to reduce the amount of information in the Accept-Language header and navigator.languages, rather than remove the header or change value format in the header. Most existing Accept-Language detection code should continue to work. This experiment should help us validate this assumption and identify corner cases.
As for interoperability, for multilingual sites to rely on the Accept-Language, developers would need to depend on a user's full Accept-Language list for some browsers and a primary user's Accept-Language for others. Another signal is that the Chrome incognito model already reduced the Accept-Language header and JS interface navigator.languages to one language, and Safari ships this behavior for many users today.
Gecko: Pending (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1014">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1014</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1014">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1014</a>>)
WebKit: Shipped (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/338">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/338</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/338">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/338</a>>) Safari already reduced the Accept-Language to a single language in most cases.
Web developers: Some web developers are concerned about the client-side language negotiation implications (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Tanych/accept-language/issues/10">https://github.com/Tanych/accept-language/issues/10</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Tanych/accept-language/issues/10">https://github.com/Tanych/accept-language/issues/10</a>>).
Experiment Goals
The goal of this experiment is to ensure web compatibility with our proposed changes. Developers can also test how reducing the Accept-Language request header and the JS getter navigator.languages will affect their systems via the chrome://flags/#reduce-accept-language flag, especially to understand the impact on client side language negotiation via navigator.languages. We will be relying heavily on user and developer feedback to identify where breakage occurs, or where use cases are not accounted for, especially for multilingual sites depending on the Accept-Language header, and navigator.languages.
Experiment Risks
There are some risks, as many multilingual sites have come to rely on the value in Accept-Language header and JS interfaces navigator.languages to send the right representation pages to the user. Site breakage can take many forms, both obvious and non-obvious - which is the point of running this experiment. If we are confident the design is largely web-compatible, we will request a Deprecation Trial for sites to be able to have time to migrate or modify how their sites work.
Debuggability
Both of these settings and the resulting network requests are visible in DevTools.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, Chrome OS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No (All but WebView)

No (We fully test in browser_tests, WPT has limits to cover all the test cases in the Accept-Language header).

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Protected+Audience%5C%3A+cross%5C-origin+trusted+signals+fetches%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Protected Audience: cross-origin trusted signals fetches</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240807" rel="nofollow">Wed, 07 Aug 2024 13:14:31 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM3
On 8/7/24 11:45 AM, Chris Harrelson wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2</pre><pre></pre><tt>On Wed, Aug 7, 2024 at 8:25 AM Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) </tt><tt><yoavwe...@chromium.org> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
LGTM1 % spec nit
On Wednesday, July 31, 2024 at 6:38:43 PM UTC+2 Paul Jensen wrote:
On Friday, July 26, 2024 at 5:28:22 AM UTC-4 Yoav Weiss wrote:
On Mon, Jul 22, 2024 at 5:26 PM 'Maksim Orlovich' via blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org> wrote:
Note: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1230">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1230</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1230">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1230</a>> is an updated link for the second spec clarification pull requests, and the first one of the two has landed.
On Fri, Jul 19, 2024 at 4:40 PM Paul Jensen <pauljen...@chromium.org> wrote:
Summary
This feature allows the Protected Audience (PA) API to fetch real-time bidding and scoring signals from origins other than the origin of the buyer and seller's scripts. This is done by enabling CORS on these requests and some additional checks and requirements, and changes to prevent misuse.
Can you expand on the "changes to prevent misuse" part? What misuse are we concerned with? What have we done to avoid it?
Previous to this proposal, the trusted signals were required to come from the same origin as the bidding or scoring script that processed them, and the script could safely assume that the signals it received were from its same origin. With this new ability to fetch them from another origin we wanted to avoid a couple forms of misuse:
1.
unintentional/accidental misconfiguration where the trusted signals origin (specified in the interest group or auction configuration) could now be a different origin but the script processing these signals might not be updated to understand this or process signals from another origin, or
2.
intentional/malicious misconfiguration where someone might have changed the origin of the trusted signals unbeknownst to the script processing them. This isn’t possible for trusted bidding signals as the interest group (where the trusted bidding signals URL is specified) is only settable from same-origin contexts.
That last part is using AsyncTask
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/probe/core_probes.h;l=83?q=AsyncTask%20f:blink&ss=chromium">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/probe/core_probes.h;l=83?q=AsyncTask%20f:blink&ss=chromium</a>>? Is that well-defined in the PR? I'm not sure we have a strict concept of "context" in the platform today. TaskAttribution <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/soft-navigations/#sec-task-attribution-algorithms">https://wicg.github.io/soft-navigations/#sec-task-attribution-algorithms</a>> took a stab at that and AsyncContext <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/tc39/proposal-async-context">https://github.com/tc39/proposal-async-context</a>> is another, but I guess that making that implementation-defined <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#implementation-defined">https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#implementation-defined</a>> would work as well for now.
1.
Auction configurations (where the trusted scoring signals URL is specified) don’t have the same same-origin setting requirements, but this is why this proposal requires the scoring script to include the Ad-Auction-Allow-Trusted-Scoring-Signals-From response header which lists allowed origins for the trusted scoring signals. Misconfiguration here could look like a scoring script allowing two trusted scoring signals origins, and someone switching between these allowed origins unexpectedly.
To prevent these misconfigurations, we changed how the trusted signals are passed to the scripts: they are passed in a new parameter so as not to be confused with the previously always-same-origin signals parameter, and this new parameter is a map from the origin of the signals to the signals themselves. This was discussed as risk #2 in my GitHub post <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/813#issuecomment-2003946175">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/813#issuecomment-2003946175</a>>.
The Ad-Auction-Allow-Trusted-Scoring-Signals-From header also prevents the trusted scoring signals request from being sent to unexpected origins.
</pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion on the web visit

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Protected+Audience%5C%3A+cross%5C-origin+trusted+signals+fetches%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Protected Audience: cross-origin trusted signals fetches</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Yoav+Weiss+%5C%28%40Shopify%5C%29%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Yoav Weiss (@Shopify)</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240807" rel="nofollow">Wed, 07 Aug 2024 08:25:08 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>LGTM1 % spec nit
On Wednesday, July 31, 2024 at 6:38:43 PM UTC+2 Paul Jensen wrote:</pre><pre>
On Friday, July 26, 2024 at 5:28:22 AM UTC-4 Yoav Weiss wrote:
On Mon, Jul 22, 2024 at 5:26 PM 'Maksim Orlovich' via blink-dev < blink-dev@chromium.org> wrote:
Note: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1230">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1230</a> is an updated link for the second spec clarification pull requests, and the first one of the two has landed.
On Fri, Jul 19, 2024 at 4:40 PM Paul Jensen <pauljen...@chromium.org> wrote:
Summary
This feature allows the Protected Audience (PA) API to fetch real-time bidding and scoring signals from origins other than the origin of the buyer and seller's scripts. This is done by enabling CORS on these requests and some additional checks and requirements, and changes to prevent misuse.
Can you expand on the "changes to prevent misuse" part? What misuse are we concerned with? What have we done to avoid it?
Previous to this proposal, the trusted signals were required to come from the same origin as the bidding or scoring script that processed them, and the script could safely assume that the signals it received were from its same origin. With this new ability to fetch them from another origin we wanted to avoid a couple forms of misuse:
1.
unintentional/accidental misconfiguration where the trusted signals origin (specified in the interest group or auction configuration) could now be a different origin but the script processing these signals might not be updated to understand this or process signals from another origin, or 2.
intentional/malicious misconfiguration where someone might have changed the origin of the trusted signals unbeknownst to the script processing them. This isn’t possible for trusted bidding signals as the interest group (where the trusted bidding signals URL is specified) is only settable from same-origin contexts.
That last part is using AsyncTask <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/probe/core_probes.h;l=83?q=AsyncTask%20f:blink&ss=chromium">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/probe/core_probes.h;l=83?q=AsyncTask%20f:blink&ss=chromium</a>>?
Is that well-defined in the PR? I'm not sure we have a strict concept of "context" in the platform today. TaskAttribution <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/soft-navigations/#sec-task-attribution-algorithms">https://wicg.github.io/soft-navigations/#sec-task-attribution-algorithms</a>> took a stab at that and AsyncContext <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/tc39/proposal-async-context">https://github.com/tc39/proposal-async-context</a>> is another, but I guess that making that implementation-defined <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#implementation-defined">https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#implementation-defined</a>> would work as well for now.
1.
Auction configurations (where the trusted scoring signals URL is specified) don’t have the same same-origin setting requirements, but this is why this proposal requires the scoring script to include the Ad-Auction-Allow-Trusted-Scoring-Signals-From response header which lists allowed origins for the trusted scoring signals. Misconfiguration here could look like a scoring script allowing two trusted scoring signals origins, and someone switching between these allowed origins unexpectedly.
To prevent these misconfigurations, we changed how the trusted signals are passed to the scripts: they are passed in a new parameter so as not to be confused with the previously always-same-origin signals parameter, and this new parameter is a map from the origin of the signals to the signals themselves. This was discussed as risk #2 in my GitHub post <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/813#issuecomment-2003946175">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/813#issuecomment-2003946175</a>>.
The Ad-Auction-Allow-Trusted-Scoring-Signals-From header also prevents the trusted scoring signals request from being sent to unexpected origins.

entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Reduce Accept-Language
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Reduce+Accept%5C-Language%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Reduce Accept-Language</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Victor+Tan%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Victor Tan</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20240807" rel="nofollow">Wed, 07 Aug 2024 08:41:44 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Email Body
Contact emails</pre><pre>
victor...@chromium.org, miketa...@chromium.org
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/reduce-accept-language</a>
TAG reviewTo be filed. Summary
In order to reduce the amount of passively available entropy in HTTP requests, we want to reduce the amount of information the Accept-Language header exposes in HTTP requests and JS interface navigator.languages. Instead of sending every user's language preferences via Accept-Language, we only send the user’s most preferred language after language negotiation in the Accept-Language header. For the HTTP Accept-Language header, we will potentially expand a base language based on the language-region pair (e.g., if the preferred language is “en-US” we will expand to “en-US, en;q=0.9”). The JS getter navigator.languages returns the same value as navigator.language.
We would like to run a Finch 1% experiment from M128 to M131 inclusive.
Blink component
Privacy>Fingerprinting <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Privacy%3EFingerprinting">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Privacy%3EFingerprinting</a>>
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
The compatibility risk is relatively low for most users since we're planning to reduce the amount of information in the Accept-Language header and navigator.languages, rather than remove the header or change value format in the header. Most existing Accept-Language detection code should continue to work. This experiment should help us validate this assumption and identify corner cases.
As for interoperability, for multilingual sites to rely on the Accept-Language, developers would need to depend on a user's full Accept-Language list for some browsers and a primary user's Accept-Language for others. Another signal is that the Chrome incognito model already reduced the Accept-Language header and JS interface navigator.languages to one language, and Safari ships this behavior for many users today.
Gecko: Pending (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1014">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1014</a>)
WebKit: Shipped (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/338">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/338</a>) Safari already reduced the Accept-Language to a single language in most cases.
Web developers: Some web developers are concerned about the client-side language negotiation implications ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Tanych/accept-language/issues/10">https://github.com/Tanych/accept-language/issues/10</a>).
Experiment Goals
The goal of this experiment is to ensure web compatibility with our proposed changes. Developers can also test how reducing the Accept-Language request header and the JS getter navigator.languages will affect their systems via the chrome://flags/#reduce-accept-language flag, especially to understand the impact on client side language negotiation via navigator.languages. We will be relying heavily on user and developer feedback to identify where breakage occurs, or where use cases are not accounted for, especially for multilingual sites depending on the Accept-Language header, and navigator.languages.
Experiment Risks
There are some risks, as many multilingual sites have come to rely on the value in Accept-Language header and JS interfaces navigator.languages to send the right representation pages to the user. Site breakage can take many forms, both obvious and non-obvious - which is the point of running this experiment. If we are confident the design is largely web-compatible, we will request a Deprecation Trial for sites to be able to have time to migrate or modify how their sites work.
Debuggability
Both of these settings and the resulting network requests are visible in DevTools.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, Chrome OS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No (All but WebView)
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
No (We fully test in browser_tests, WPT has limits to cover all the test cases in the Accept-Language header).

Summary This feature allows for ARIA relationship attributes to be reflected in IDL as element references rather than DOMStrings.
Note: This intent specifically concerns the ARIA attributes using Element Reflection, i.e. the attributes in the ARIAMixin interface with a type of Element or FrozenArray<Element>. popoverTargetElement, which also uses Element Reflection, is already shipping in Blink and WebKit.
Blink component Blink>DOM
TAG review <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/134">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/134</a>
TAG review status Issues addressed
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
